docs.snippet: LEAD: For Latin Americans, especially her fellow Argentines, Mercedes Sosa is like Joan Baez, Linda Ronstadt and Paul Robeson rolled into one. With her magnificent voice she sings about the dignity of the poor and about the hope for freedom backed by...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For Latin Americans, especially her fellow Argentines, Mercedes Sosa is like Joan Baez, Linda Ronstadt and Paul Robeson rolled into one. With her magnificent voice she sings about the dignity of the poor and about the hope for freedom backed by the willingness to struggle; the songs vow that human dignity will survive and eventually prevail.

headline.main: Review/Concert; Latin American Voice For Dignity and Hope

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States warned today of escalating trade wars with the European Community if the Europeans do not agree to a timetable this year for long-term elimination of agricultural export subsidies.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The United States warned today of escalating trade wars with the European Community if the Europeans do not agree to a timetable this year for long-term elimination of agricultural export subsidies.

headline.main: U.S. Warns Europeans To Cut Farm Subsidies

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: ROLLING grasslands, English pedigree sheep and a climate similar to that of New Zealand have long made Uruguay a leading exporter of fine wool. And for the last 20 years, this small South American nation has also been the source of richly...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ROLLING grasslands, English pedigree sheep and a climate similar to that of New Zealand have long made Uruguay a leading exporter of fine wool. And for the last 20 years, this small South American nation has also been the source of richly colored handknits, the creation of a knitting cooperative called Manos del Uruguay.

byline.original: By KATHLEEN WHEATON; KATHLEEN WHEATON is a writer who lives in New York

docs.snippet: LEAD: There is a magnificently simple vision behind the European Community's plans to remove internal trade barriers in 1992: help the 12-nation community grow faster by encouraging more competition and efficiency.

headline.main: The Growing Fear of Fortress Europe

docs.snippet: LEAD: Averting a trade conflict with Japan in the heat of an American political campaign, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, rejected a petition today from domestic rice growers seeking immediate access to the $35...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Averting a trade conflict with Japan in the heat of an American political campaign, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, rejected a petition today from domestic rice growers seeking immediate access to the $35 billion-a-year Japanese rice market.

headline.main: U.S. Rejects Action on Japan's Rice Imports

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Seven South American Presidents pledged today to devise a strategy to persuade creditors to write off part of their $339 billion debt.

docs.snippet: LEAD:  The Caribbean: President Reagan, seeking to diminish what he calls Cuban and Soviet influence in Central America and the Caribbean, meets with the new conservative Prime Minister of Jamaica, Edward P. G. Seaga, in 1981 and promises economic...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Caribbean: President Reagan, seeking to diminish what he calls Cuban and Soviet influence in Central America and the Caribbean, meets with the new conservative Prime Minister of Jamaica, Edward P. G. Seaga, in 1981 and promises economic aid. In 1983, the region's English-speaking islands support the American invasion of Grenada.

headline.main: The Reagan Years In the Region

docs.snippet: LEAD: In proclaiming the success of its policy toward Latin America, the Reagan Administration has identified ''the greatest expansion of democracy in Latin history'' as its central achievement. Yet not for the first time, the perspective from...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In proclaiming the success of its policy toward Latin America, the Reagan Administration has identified ''the greatest expansion of democracy in Latin history'' as its central achievement. Yet not for the first time, the perspective from Washington is not the view south of the border.

headline.main: DEMOCRAT AND DEBT: U.S. POLICY ON LATIN AMERICA IS WELL RECEIVED - IN WASHINGTON

docs.snippet: LEAD: In the first test of the Administration under the new trade law, reason has prevailed. Clayton Yeutter, the Government's chief trade official, has rejected a plea by American rice growers to investigate Japan's ban on rice imports....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In the first test of the Administration under the new trade law, reason has prevailed. Clayton Yeutter, the Government's chief trade official, has rejected a plea by American rice growers to investigate Japan's ban on rice imports. Election-year politics and the facts of the case might have favored the rice growers, but Mr.

headline.main: The Political Price of Rice, Resisted
